ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: how to read selected texts and analyze them
I learned how to evaluate short essays for writing style and really improved in my personal essay writing.
I think my writing improved, mainly in my ability to write a thematically cohesive essay. My style also improved. We also read a lot of good essays, which is fun in itself!

I learned a lot about how to read an essay and then take the rhetorical devices used by the authors and apply them to my own work. I think that I improved a lot through identifying how others make their prose so strong.
Developed writing skills and techniques as well as how to analyze texts.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Good and varied syllabus; good feedback
Weaknesses: The routine of finding techniques to replicate becomes a bit monotonous
mediocre feedback on essays and lack of clear guidelines and expectations

Strengths: I really liked a lot of the readings we did, and the reading load before each class was never too much while also giving us enough to discuss in class. I also think that the instructor feedback on essays was really comprehensive and genuinely helped me improve as a writer. It was also nice to be able to choose one essay not to write.

Weaknesses: A few of the readings were not that engaging. Also,

Strengths: Good professors, fun class exercises, cool essay topics. Weaknesses: Becomes a little repetitive by the end, discussion was mainly shepherded by professor so it felt forced at times (students wanted to talk, but professor took a lot of discussion time)

There were so many strengths of the course--I loved the essay prompts (just broad enough), and I also loved all of the essays chosen by the professor. I think the course could have been improved just through different classroom dynamics; often, the conversation felt very imbalanced.
Strengths of this class are the different types of texts you get to read and how theres something interest for everyone at some point.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: For students interested in creative nonfiction, yes. Otherwise, Im not sure how applicable the writing skills are other than to hone style.
no, did not really teach how to write a better essay or be a better writer

Yes, I think it really improves your personal essay writing and lets you 'borrow' techniques that great essay writers have used. Also, you receive really great feedback on each essay! Having been said, it is more work than ENGL 114 because essays are graded more on writing technique than content, so you will have to revise your final drafts a lot. I would still recommend it as a writing credit though, especially if you are planning on applying to grad school and have to write personal essays in the future. I would definitely take ENGL 120 with Craig if you can because he's a great teacher/person!

Yes! But there might be a better WR credit if you want to improve academic writing. Mine certainly improved as a result of ENGL 120 lessons, and the essays are a lot of fun to write (especially humor/satire!), but it's not academic writing.

I would absolutely recommend this course. It was so much fun to attend every day. The reading was not too much, and it also felt helpful and relevant to the writing assignments given. I loved coming to class and could count on always walking out of ENGL 120 in a better mood than when I entered it.
Yes, I would. It was a great writing class where you learned a lot over the course of the semester and for the most part the writing always felt fun because you had complete freedom.
